item.title: Docker-izing your work in R ğŸ³
item.description: Updated: 2018-08-19 I am decidedly a novice when it comes to any and all things Docker (which, incidentally, is why Iâ€™ve been reading these posts). But, since itâ€™s helpful for me to have all of these resources together in one place, I thought Iâ€™d share the love around.1 R Docker turorial for reproducible research. via rOpenSci Labs This is actually a series of 6 lessons put together at the rOpenSci unconf in 2016.

item.title: Onboarding with rOpenSci: Tandem tales of package review
item.description: On of the ways in which rOpenSci does such a stellar job of package â€œquality controlâ€ is through its open, peer-review onboarding process. I had the chance to take part in this by reviewing Nicholas Tierneyâ€™s awesome visdat package ğŸ“¦. In what Iâ€™m told is an rOpenSci first, Nick and I both wrote up our experiences for the rOpenSci blog â€” giving you a peek into the reviewer and reviewee process.

item.title: Ceci n'est pas un conf.
item.description: Meta lesson learned This is not the post I originally intended to write about the rOpenSci Unconf (and, I promise, this isnâ€™t just a lame attempt to take the Magritte joke a step further). Rather, what follows is wisdom gleaned both at the unconf, and in in my (failed) attempts to write the aforementioned original post capturing my unconf experience.1 HUGOMORE42 In our two days of un-conferring, there were 20 packages written by ~70 participants.
